hobby.message: Origami help keep the noise out?
Find any ghosts in the tunnels?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Quieter than usual. Depends what you listen for.
Too much noise lately, but not the kind I mind.
Spent the afternoon with my typewriters, restoring an old Mishin.
Blackouts slowed me down. Got by with candlelight.
Depends. I avoid the crowds when they get worked up.
You know, the old machines don't protest power cuts.
Had a Mishin portable on my desk—mechanical, needs no data feed.
The blackout forced me to finish repairs by candlelight.
Fits the week we've had—city's details keep vanishing.
Loud outside, quiet in my apartment. Funny how they're never the same.
Spent the day reclaiming an old typewriter—gives me peace of mind.
Not many left who still care for keys and ribbons.
These outages—had to use candle stub just to see the work.
Honestly, there's comfort in things that don't update themselves.
Last week shows: power's less reliable than my old Mishin.
City's restless, but my flat's not much better these days.
Power went out while I was fixing an old manual typewriter.
Long hours with that Mishin, ribbon ink staining my fingers.
Always liked how the machine doesn't care about BCI fluctuations.
During the data strike, I wrote a bit by candle just to prove I could.
Mechanical keys give clean answers—no logs, no judgment, just what you type.
Makes you wonder how we let everything else get so tangled.
Today? Only if you count the chaos hiding in every service alert.
My hobby? Restoring vintage typewriters—mechanical, not even BCI can track them.
Been working on a Mishin portable, Soviet make. Solid, timeless.
During last week's data blackout, I journaled by candle. No system could touch those words.
The strike reminded me—sometimes, surviving means using what they can't see.
Back when I was at the Secretariat, even I needed simple tools. Paper, keys, ink.
Now, with every outage, my hobby's a small rebellion—proof I still exist.
Funny, in a way: the city gets louder, but the typewriter stays honest.
hobby_answer: Still do. Mostly old portables, nothing rare.
Spare time's best spent on things you can hold.
Power cuts made work a chore lately.
Anything mechanical feels safer these days.
Can’t say more, you know how it is.
Yes, still collecting. Fewer now, mostly local types.
Power outage last week almost ruined a ribbon replacement.
Crowd outside my window, system flickered all day.
Odd how useful a manual machine feels now.
I keep writing, even if no one reads it.
Better not to mention what gets written.
Yes, still at it. Typewriters are less cooperative in the dark, though.
Lost three hours during the blackout, nearly jammed a mainspring.
Funny—no logins, no biometric nonsense, just ink and mechanics.
Wrote a few pages by candlelight during the worst of it.
Crowds gathered downstairs, but I stayed upstairs with my work.
Things outside changed, but the click and clack stayed familiar.
Makes the chaos feel a bit smaller.
Still collecting, yes. Old Mishin is my current headache.
Last week’s blackout—had to type by candle, like old times.
Door locks froze, neighbors were improvising a ladder.
Even so, manual machines just work. No permissions, no scores.
I wrote about it—small defiance, really.
Always trusted things that leave a mark you can hold.
I sort pages in my briefcase; some are… more cautious than others.
Strange, how vital a mechanical habit becomes when the city forgets you.
Absolutely, and I’ve been at it since before BCI days.
Manual portables remind me of my father’s shop, long before the system.
During the data strike, power grid failed. Candlelight, ink-smudged thumbs, windows fogged over.
Neighbors knocked, locked out by their own doors. I kept my head down, kept typing.
Wrote out everything I couldn’t say—city losing its memory, people vanishing from records.
Pages go into the briefcase; not all for public eyes, as you’d guess.
I mark the date every time the city shifts. Makes gaps in the archive.
When system’s unstable, a typewriter’s permanence keeps me rooted.
Truth told, I trust paper more than the Council or their machines.
